protocol.name: FOLFOX Chemotherapy for Colorectal Cancer (Adjuvant)
protocol.overview: Modified FOLFOX6 regimen for adjuvant treatment of stage III colon cancer following surgical resection. This protocol combines oxaliplatin, leucovorin, and 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) administered every 2 weeks for 12 cycles (24 weeks total). Based on MOSAIC trial and NCCN guidelines.
evidence_sources: Andre T, et al. N Engl J Med. 2004;350(23):2343-2351 (MOSAIC trial)
NCCN Clinical Practice Guidelines in Oncology: Colon Cancer v2.2024
FDA approval for oxaliplatin in combination with 5-FU/LV

steps.title: Oncology Consultation & Treatment Planning
steps.description: Comprehensive oncology consultation to review pathology, staging, discuss treatment goals, risks/benefits, and obtain informed consent for adjuvant chemotherapy.

documentation_requirements.staging: Pathologic stage (TNM), number of nodes examined and positive
documentation_requirements.surgery: Type and date of resection, margin status, complications
documentation_requirements.performance_status: ECOG performance status (0-2 required for treatment)

informed_consent_topics: Rationale for adjuvant chemotherapy (reduction in recurrence risk)
Common side effects (neuropathy, nausea, diarrhea, fatigue, cytopenias)
Serious risks (neutropenic fever, severe neuropathy, allergic reactions)
Right to refuse or discontinue treatment

steps.title: Pre-Treatment Assessment & Baseline Labs
steps.description: Comprehensive baseline assessment including laboratory tests, imaging, and functional assessments required before chemotherapy initiation.
lab_tests_required: Comprehensive Metabolic Panel (CMP) including creatinine, liver enzymes
Blood type and screen (if port placement planned)

functional_assessments.requirement: Must be 0-2 to proceed with treatment

functional_assessments.purpose: Assess for malnutrition, plan supportive care

steps.title: Vascular Access Placement (Optional)
steps.description: Placement of central venous catheter (port-a-cath or PICC) for chemotherapy administration and labs if needed. Not required but often preferred for patient comfort.
post_placement_requirements: Chest X-ray to confirm position (for PICC/port)
Patient education on care and flushing

steps.title: Chemotherapy Dose Calculation & Regimen Confirmation
steps.description: Calculate individualized chemotherapy doses based on body surface area (BSA) and renal function. Confirm FOLFOX6 regimen dosing.

dose_capping.rationale: Reduce toxicity in very large patients without compromising efficacy

day_1_drugs.route: IV infusion over 2 hours (concurrent with oxaliplatin)
Continuous IV infusion over 46 hours via pump

branch_outcomes.description: Normal renal function, standard FOLFOX6 doses calculated

steps.title: Pre-Chemotherapy Patient Education
steps.description: Comprehensive education session covering chemotherapy administration, expected side effects, self-care strategies, and emergency contact information.

education_topics.content: 12 cycles every 2 weeks (total 24 weeks), Day 1 infusion (~6 hours), Day 3 pump disconnect, labs before each cycle

content: Neuropathy (cold sensitivity, numbness/tingling) - cumulative with oxaliplatin
Nausea/vomiting - usually controlled with medications
Diarrhea - take anti-diarrheal as prescribed
Fatigue - pace yourself, rest as needed
Mouth sores - good oral hygiene, avoid spicy/acidic foods
Hair thinning (not complete baldness typically)

education_topics.content: Avoid crowds, wash hands frequently, report fever > 100.4°F immediately
Avoid cold drinks/foods for 3-5 days after treatment, wear gloves for cold items, no ice
Wear pump in provided pouch, avoid getting wet, return if alarm sounds or stops working
Anti-nausea, anti-diarrheal, growth factors if needed - when and how to take

content: Fever ≥ 100.4°F (neutropenic fever emergency)
Severe diarrhea (> 6 stools/day or bloody)
Difficulty breathing or chest pain
Severe allergic reaction (rash, swelling, wheezing)
Uncontrolled nausea/vomiting
Signs of blood clots (leg pain, swelling, redness)

steps.title: Cycle 1, Day 1 - Chemotherapy Infusion
steps.description: First chemotherapy treatment with FOLFOX regimen. Includes pre-medications, oxaliplatin, leucovorin, 5-FU bolus, and connection of 5-FU continuous infusion pump.

pre_medications.dose: Ondansetron 16-24 mg IV or Palonosetron 0.25 mg IV

infusion_sequence.special_instructions: Do NOT use ice for extravasation. Oxaliplatin in D5W (never saline)

infusion_sequence.route: Continuous IV infusion via portable pump
infusion_sequence.timing: Immediately after bolus, patient goes home with pump

vitals_monitoring.infusion_reaction_watch: Especially during oxaliplatin - monitor for bronchospasm, rash, hypotension

nursing_assessments: IV site patency and phlebitis monitoring
discharge_criteria: Patient/caregiver understands pump care and emergency instructions
Prescriptions provided for home anti-emetics and anti-diarrheals

safety_checks.requirement: Two RN verification of patient identity, drug, dose, route per institutional policy
Available at bedside - note: NO ice for oxaliplatin extravasation

steps.title: Cycle 1, Day 3 - 5-FU Pump Disconnect
steps.description: Patient returns to clinic for removal of 5-FU continuous infusion pump, assessment of acute toxicities, and supportive care.
assessments: Pump completion verification (should be empty or near-empty)
IV site assessment (if peripheral) or port access site
interventions: Remove and dispose of 5-FU pump per chemotherapy waste protocol
Flush port or remove peripheral IV
Patient education reinforcement on delayed side effects

symptom_management.nausea: Prescribe additional anti-emetics if breakthrough nausea
symptom_management.cold_sensitivity: Reassure temporary, avoid cold for 3-5 days

steps.title: Mid-Cycle Phone Follow-up (Day 7-10)
steps.description: Nurse-initiated phone call to assess delayed side effects, medication adherence, and supportive care needs between cycles.
assessment_checklist: Diarrhea (number of stools per day, hydration status)
Neuropathy symptoms (cold sensitivity resolved? any numbness/tingling?)
Medication adherence and any issues with prescriptions
Questions or concerns for next treatment
red_flag_symptoms_requiring_immediate_es: Severe diarrhea (> 6 stools/day or bloody stools)
steps.documentation: Document call in EMR, escalate concerns to oncologist, provide reassurance and supportive care guidance

steps.title: Pre-Cycle Labs & Treatment Decision (Day 14)
steps.description: Laboratory assessment before each cycle to determine fitness to proceed with chemotherapy, need for dose adjustments, or treatment delays.

delay_criteria.action: Hold oxaliplatin until ≤ Grade 1, consider dose reduction
Delay until resolved to Grade 1, reduce 5-FU dose by 20%

dose_reduction_criteria.dose_modification: Consider reducing oxaliplatin from 85 to 75 mg/m² after cycle 6-8

discontinuation_criteria.action: Discontinue oxaliplatin permanently, continue 5-FU/LV if appropriate
Consider treatment discontinuation or palliative care

branch_outcomes.description: Labs adequate, no significant toxicities, proceed with standard doses
Prior toxicities require dose reduction, proceed with modified doses
Cytopenias or toxicities not resolved, delay treatment 1 week
Severe toxicity, modify regimen (e.g., discontinue oxaliplatin, continue 5-FU)
Unacceptable toxicity or progression, stop chemotherapy

steps.title: Subsequent Cycles (Cycles 2-12)
steps.description: Repeat cycles of FOLFOX chemotherapy following same sequence as Cycle 1, with dose adjustments as determined by toxicity assessments.
steps.cycle_components: Repeat steps 6-9 for each cycle with toxicity-driven modifications

neuropathy.concern: Cumulative with oxaliplatin, often worsens after cycles 8-10
neuropathy.monitoring: Assess grade at each visit, patient-reported numbness/tingling diary
neuropathy.management: Dose reduction or discontinuation based on grade and impact on function

fatigue.concern: Cumulative fatigue increases over treatment course
fatigue.management: Activity balance, nutritional support, rule out anemia

cytopenias.concern: Bone marrow reserve may diminish over time
cytopenias.management: Dose reductions or G-CSF support if recurrent neutropenia

special_cycle_considerations.cycle_6: Mid-treatment assessment, consider imaging if symptoms suggest progression
special_cycle_considerations.cycle_9_10: Neuropathy often peaks, many patients require oxaliplatin dose reduction or early discontinuation
special_cycle_considerations.cycle_12: Final cycle - schedule restaging scans and survivorship planning

steps.title: Restaging Imaging & Response Assessment
steps.description: CT scans performed after cycles 4, 8, and 12 to assess for disease recurrence (though rare in adjuvant setting) and post-treatment surveillance planning.

imaging_schedule.purpose: Early assessment, rule out progression (rare but important to catch early)

outcomes.action: Continue planned treatment to completion, proceed to survivorship care
Stop adjuvant protocol, discuss metastatic treatment options
Multidisciplinary tumor board, consider surgery/radiation +/- chemotherapy change

additional_monitoring.cea_levels: Check CEA with each restaging scan, rising CEA may indicate recurrence even if scans negative

branch_outcomes.description: No recurrence, continue adjuvant chemotherapy as planned

steps.title: Treatment Completion & Survivorship Planning
steps.description: Final visit after completing 12 cycles of FOLFOX. Review treatment summary, discuss surveillance plan, address long-term side effects, and transition to survivorship care.
completion_assessments: Residual neuropathy grade (often persists for months after oxaliplatin completion)

survivorship_care_plan_components.content: Diagnosis, stage, surgery date, chemotherapy regimen and doses, toxicities experienced, final scans

content: History & Physical: Every 3-6 months for 2 years, then every 6 months for years 3-5, then annually
CEA: Every 3-6 months for 2 years (if elevated at diagnosis)
CT chest/abdomen/pelvis: Annually for 3-5 years
Colonoscopy: 1 year after surgery, then per guidelines based on findings
Neuropathy: May persist for 6-12 months or longer; refer to neurology if severe
Fatigue: Gradual improvement expected over 6-12 months
Cognitive changes: 'Chemo brain' may occur, usually improves with time
Fertility: May be impaired; refer to reproductive endocrinology if pregnancy desired
Secondary malignancies: Small increased risk; maintain cancer screening
Diet: Balanced diet, maintain healthy weight
Exercise: Goal of 150 minutes moderate activity per week
Smoking cessation: Critical for reducing recurrence risk
Alcohol: Limit intake
Sun protection
Cancer survivorship support groups
Individual counseling if needed for anxiety/depression
Financial counseling for treatment costs
Return to work planning

survivorship_care_plan_components.content: Symptoms that should prompt immediate evaluation: abdominal pain, rectal bleeding, unexplained weight loss, persistent cough, bone pain

referrals: Primary care physician (send survivorship care plan)

port_removal.timing: Can remove 4-8 weeks after final treatment if no longer needed
port_removal.discussion: Discuss pros/cons of keeping vs. removing with patient

acute: Palonosetron 0.25 mg IV or ondansetron 16-24 mg IV day 1
Consider NK-1 antagonist (aprepitant) for high-risk patients
delayed: Ondansetron 8 mg PO q8h as needed days 2-5
breakthrough: Olanzapine 5-10 mg PO daily (very effective for refractory nausea)

diarrhea_management.prevention: Loperamide 2 mg after each loose stool, max 16 mg/day
diarrhea_management.severe_diarrhea: Hold chemotherapy, hydration (IV if needed), consider hospitalization for Grade 3-4

neuropathy_management.pharmacologic: Duloxetine 30-60 mg daily (evidence-based for chemotherapy-induced neuropathy)
neuropathy_management.non_pharmacologic: Occupational therapy, hand/foot warming, compression gloves

neutropenia_management.prophylactic_gcsf: Generally not needed for FOLFOX, but consider if recurrent neutropenia or neutropenic fever

mucositis_prevention.oral_cryotherapy: Ice chips during 5-FU bolus (may reduce mucositis)
mucositis_prevention.oral_care: Gentle brushing, alcohol-free mouthwash, salt/soda rinses

hand_foot_syndrome.prevention: Moisturize hands/feet, avoid heat, wear comfortable shoes

serious_adverse_events.management: Emergency! Immediate hospitalization, broad-spectrum antibiotics, G-CSF
serious_adverse_events.future_prevention: Dose reduction or G-CSF prophylaxis for subsequent cycles

serious_adverse_events.incidence: Rare but can occur, more common with cumulative cycles

serious_adverse_events.management: Hospitalization for IV hydration, hold chemotherapy, dose reduction when resume

serious_adverse_events.risk: Cancer patients have increased VTE risk
serious_adverse_events.management: Anticoagulation, consider holding chemotherapy if life-threatening PE
serious_adverse_events.prevention: Early mobilization, consider prophylaxis in high-risk patients

serious_adverse_events.management: Hold 5-FU, topical steroids, dose reduction when resume

considerations: Increased toxicity risk, especially neuropathy and cytopenias
Consider dose reduction (80% starting dose) or alternative regimen (CAPOX, 5-FU/LV alone)

renal_impairment.mild_moderate: Reduce oxaliplatin dose as per protocol
renal_impairment.severe: Consider alternative regimen without oxaliplatin or close nephrology collaboration

quality_metrics.toxicity_rates: Monitor Grade 3-4 toxicity rates, neutropenic fever, hospitalizations
quality_metrics.patient_satisfaction: Quality of life assessments, symptom management adequacy
